report:
FINDINGS:



Vascular:
Arteries: The ascending thoracic aorta, great vessels and descending thoracic
aorta appear patent and unremarkable.  There is no aneurysmal dilatation.

There is mild atherosclerotic calcification of the abdominal aorta and its
branches.

There is no significant soft tissue stranding along the celiac artery.  There
is soft tissue thickening surrounding the hip common hepatic artery with
severe stenosis.  There is also soft tissue thickening surrounding the splenic
artery.  The left gastric artery does not appear involved.

The superior mesenteric artery and its branches does not appear involved.

The bilateral renal arteries are patent.  The ___ is patent.

The bilateral common iliac arteries, internal external iliac arteries as well
as the common femoral and proximal superficial and deep femoral arteries are
patent.

Venous: There is thrombus within the right subclavian extending along the
right Port-A-Cath.

The right and left iliac veins are patent.  The infrarenal and infrahepatic
IVC is patent.  There is mass effect on the IVC with narrowing.  There is
narrowing of the hepatic veins due to metastatic disease.  The super hepatic
IVC is also patent.

The splenic vein is patent.  There is occlusion of the superior mesenteric
vein and portal vein.  Within numerable paraesophageal, perisplenic,
perigastric and porta hepatic varices.  There is no evidence of thrombosis.

Chest:

Heart and vasculature: Pulmonary vasculature is well opacified to the
subsegmental level without filling defect to indicate a pulmonary embolus. 
Evaluation is slightly limited due to respiratory motion.  The thoracic aorta
is normal in caliber without evidence of dissection or intramural hematoma. 
The heart, pericardium, and great vessels are within normal limits. No
pericardial effusion is seen.

Axilla, hila, and mediastinum: There is decrease in the previously noted
mediastinal lymphadenopathy.  The previously noted 10 mm prevascular lymph
node now measures 0.8 cm (series 21, image 36).  The previously noted 1.2 cm
right paratracheal lymph node now measures 0.9 cm (series 21, image 37). 
Esophagus now appears within normal limits.

There is resolution of the previously noted mediastinal emphysema.

Pleural spaces: There are post treatment changes from right talc pleurodesis. 
Again seen is a large right hydropneumothorax along the fissure which contains
air and a small fluid component.  This is similar in size to ___.

There remains a multiloculated right pleural effusion at the apex of the right
hemithorax and tracking along the medial aspect which is similar in size to ___.  Again is seen a small loculated pleural effusion near the lung
base (series 21, image 52).

Lungs/airways: There is stable biapical pleuroparenchymal scarring.  Again
seen is extensive atelectasis of the right middle lobe and right lung base. 
The previously noted pulmonary nodule at the left upper lobe is not well
characterized due to respiratory motion (series 8, image 42). There are no new
pulmonary nodules.

Chest wall: There is a right-sided Port-A-Cath with its tip at the proximal
SVC.  There is decrease in the extensive subcutaneous emphysema tracking from
the lung at the lower right mid axillary line. There is now trace subcutaneous
emphysema with trace air along the pectoralis muscle and extending into the
soft tissues of the shoulder.

Base of neck:  There is near complete resolution of the subcutaneous air
tracking along the left neck. Visualized portions of the base of the neck show
no abnormality.

Abdomen:

Hepatobiliary: There are innumerable hypoattenuating lesions scattered
throughout the spleen concerning for metastatic disease.  The largest lesions
in the left lobe liver measures up to 5.5 cm in diameter (series 21, image
103).  There is intrahepatic biliary ductal dilatation with trace pneumobilia
status post placement of a ___ BD.  Biliary ductal dilatation is better
characterized MRCP from ___.  Interval change is not well assessed
due to streak artifact from adjacent hardware and phase of contrast. The
gallbladder is surgically absent.

There remains a heterogeneously enhancing mass near the porta hepatis
consistent with the known pancreatic lesion.

Pancreas: There is a mass at the expected location of the head of the pancreas
measuring approximately 8.0 x 9.9 x 8.3 cm (AP by TV by CC).  There are
fiducial markers again seen within the lesion.  There is diffuse atrophy of
the residual body and tail the pancreas without evidence of ductal dilatation.

Spleen: There is marked splenomegaly measuring 15.9 cm in craniocaudal
dimension.  There is homogeneous attenuation throughout, without evidence of
focal lesions.

Adrenals: The right and left adrenal glands are normal in size and shape.

Urinary: The kidneys are of normal and symmetric size with normal nephrogram.
There is no evidence of stones, solid renal lesions, or hydronephrosis. There
are no urothelial lesions in the kidneys or ureters. There is no perinephric
abnormality.

Gastrointestinal: There are postsurgical changes from gastrojejunostomy. 
Contours of the duodenum are not well characterized due to loss of fat planes
from the adjacent mass.  The bowel appears nonobstructed.  Small bowel loops
demonstrate normal caliber wall thickness throughout.  The colon and rectum
are within normal limits.

Retroperitoneum: There is no evidence of retroperitoneal lymphadenopathy.

Pelvis: The urinary bladder and distal ureters are unremarkable.  There is no
evidence of pelvic or inguinal lymphadenopathy.  There is large volume ascites
diffusely within the abdomen including perihepatic, perisplenic, bilateral
paracolic gutters, mesenteric and within the pelvis.  This is similar prior
imaging.

Reproductive organs: The visualized reproductive organs are unremarkable.

Bones: There is no evidence of worrisome osseous lesions or acute fracture.

Soft tissues: There is diastasis of the rectus muscles.  The abdominal and
pelvic wall is within normal limits.


IMPRESSION:



1. There is thrombus at the right subclavian vein along the right Porta-Cath. 
There is no evidence of pulmonary embolism.
2. Stable post treatment changes from talc pleurodesis with persistent
hydropneumothorax and multiloculated pleural effusions as described above.
3. Interval decrease in subcutaneous emphysema since ___.
4. The previously noted prominent mediastinal lymph nodes have decreased in
size as described above.
5. There is occlusion of the superior mesenteric vein and portal vein with
collateral varices.
6. Again seen is ill-defined, heterogeneous enhancing mass at the head of the
pancreas with atrophy of the body and tail.
7. Innumerable metastatic lesions within the liver.
8. Postsurgical changes from gastrojejunostomy.
9. Interval placement of a ___ BD drain.  Again seen is biliary dilatation. 
Interval change is not well assessed due to phase of contrast and streak
artifact.
10. Large volume ascites diffusely within the abdomen/pelvis which appears
similar to ___.  Malignant ascites cannot be excluded.

FINDINGS:



Heart and vasculature: Evaluation of segmental and subsegmental pulmonary
arteries in the left lower lobe lung is suboptimal due to respiratory motion. 
Pulmonary vasculature is otherwise well opacified to the subsegmental level
without filling defect to indicate a pulmonary embolus.  The thoracic aorta is
normal in caliber without evidence of dissection or intramural hematoma.  The 
heart is normal in size with diffuse coronary artery calcifications.  No
pericardial effusion is seen.  A right chest wall Port-A-Cath terminates in
the upper right atrium.

Axilla, hila, and mediastinum: No axillary, mediastinal, or hilar
lymphadenopathy is present.  No mediastinal mass.

Pleural spaces: There is a new trace left pleural effusion.  No pneumothorax.

Lungs/airways: There are new enhancing consolidations in the left lower medial
lobe and in the lingula.  There is a new 6 mm pulmonary nodule in the right
lower lobe (3:143).  Additional smaller areas of ground-glass nodularity in
the right lung are not significantly changed.  There are scattered punctate
calcified granulomas.  The airways are patent to the level of the segmental
bronchi bilaterally.

Base of neck: Visualized portions of the base of the neck show no abnormality.

Abdomen: Hepatic hypodensities are partially visualized, however do not appear
significantly changed.  The spleen is enlarged up to 15 cm, not significantly
changed.  There is a 1 cm enhancing focus in the anterior spleen which does
not appear significantly changed, possibly a hemangioma.  Included portion of
the upper abdomen is otherwise unremarkable.

Bones: No suspicious osseous abnormality is seen.? There is no acute fracture.



IMPRESSION:



1. Limited evaluation of the segmental and subsegmental pulmonary arteries in
the left lower lung due to respiratory motion. Otherwise no evidence of
pulmonary embolism or aortic abnormality.
2. New small left pleural effusion and increased small consolidations in the
medial left lower lobe and lingula which may represent atelectasis, however
superimposed infection is difficult to exclude.
3. New 6 mm right lower lobe pulmonary nodule, nonspecific, may be infectious
or inflammatory in nature. Additional previously seen nodular opacities in the
lungs are not significantly changed.

FINDINGS:

 The pulmonary arteries are opacified to subsegmental levels
bilaterally, without evidence of acute pulmonary embolism.  The aorta has
moderate atherosclerotic calcification, without aneurysmal dilation or
dissection.  The heart is enlarged.  Dense mitral annular calcifications are
present.  Small scattered mediastinal lymph nodes, including a 7-mm right
lower paratracheal node are stable.  No pathologic central lymphadenopathy is
seen.

The major airways are patent bilaterally.  Mild prominence of the septa and
bilateral pleural effusions, small on the right and moderate on the left, are
consistent with pulmonary edema. (2:53). A 3 mm right middle lobe nodule,
stable for over ___ years still remains unchanged.  Compressive atelectasis in
the dependent portion of both lower lobes, limit evaluation of previously seen
likely benign lower lobe nodules.

This study is not tailored for subdiaphragmatic assessment, except to note
moderate intrahepatic biliary dilatation, more pronounced in the left hepatic
lobe, the cause of which is not assessed in this study.

Bones:  No bone lesion suspicious for infection or malignancy is detected.  No
acute fractures are seen.  Old healed right posterior rib fractures. Stable
moderate compression deformities of T3 and T9 vertebral bodies are unchanged
since ___.


IMPRESSION:

1.  No pulmonary embolism.
2.  Small right/moderate left pleural effusions and mild interstitial edema.
3.  Moderate cardiomegaly.  Dense mitral valvular calcifications, of unknown
hemodynamic significance. 
4.  Moderate intrahepatic biliary dilatation, dedicated imaging either CT or
MRCP can be obtained for further assessment.

FINDINGS:



The aorta and its major branch vessels are patent, with no evidence of
stenosis, occlusion, dissection, or aneurysmal formation.  There is no
evidence of penetrating atherosclerotic ulcer or aortic arch atheroma present.

The pulmonary arteries are well opacified to the subsegmental level, with no
evidence of filling defect within the main, right, left, lobar, segmental or
subsegmental pulmonary arteries.  The main and right pulmonary arteries are
normal in caliber, and there is no evidence of right heart strain.

There is no supraclavicular, axillary, mediastinal, or hilar lymphadenopathy. 
Right thyroid lobe is not well visualized.

There is no evidence of pericardial effusion.  There is no pleural effusion.

There is a 5 mm nodule in the right lower lobe (3:148).  This is new from the
prior CTA in ___.  The airways are patent to the subsegmental level.

Limited images of the upper abdomen are unremarkable.

No lytic or blastic osseous lesion suspicious for malignancy is identified.


IMPRESSION:



1. No evidence of pulmonary embolism or aortic abnormality.
2. Lower lobe pulmonary nodule new from ___, 5 mm on the right.

FINDINGS:



THYROID,  LYMPH NODES & MEDIASTINUM: The thyroid is normal.  There is
increased left hilar soft tissue measuring up to 2.1 x 3.3 cm, minimally
increased in size from the PET-CT in ___.  Few prominent mediastinal
lymph nodes are not pathologically enlarged.  A 9 mm right hilar lymph node is
stable (2a: 48).

HEART & VESSELS: The heart is normal in size.  There is mild to moderate
calcified coronary artery atherosclerosis.  The great vessels are normal in
caliber.  There is no evidence of pulmonary embolism to the subsegmental
level.

LUNGS & AIRWAYS: There is complete collapse of left upper lobe.  There is a
small left pleural effusion as well as atelectasis involving left lower lobe. 
There is severe centrilobular and paraseptal emphysema as before.  Increased
opacity throughout the inferior right upper lobe and right lower lobe likely
reflects atelectasis and scarring.  There the left upper lobe bronchus is
completely collapsed.  The remainder of the bronchial tree shows areas of
distal mucoid impaction involving multiple segmental and subsegmental
branches.


Hepatobiliary: The liver is normal in size and attenuation.  The portal vein
is patent.  The patient is status post cholecystectomy with clips in the
gallbladder fossa.

Spleen: The spleen is normal.

Pancreas: Pancreas is normal with no pancreatic lesions identified.  There is
no peripancreatic fat stranding.

Adrenals: The adrenals are normal.

Urinary: The kidneys are normal in size and display symmetric nephrograms. 
There is no hydronephrosis.

Gastrointestinal: The stomach is within normal limits.  There is a small
hiatal hernia.  There is a focally dilated loop of small bowel within the left
upper quadrant measuring up to 3.7 cm.  Distal loops of small bowel contain
stool and gas and there is no definite transition point identified.  The
appendix measures up to 6 mm however there is no periappendiceal fat
stranding.

Lymph nodes: There is no intra-abdominal lymphadenopathy by CT size criteria.

Vascular: The aorta is normal in caliber and shows heavy calcified
atherosclerosis.

Pelvis: The bladder is moderately distended.  Within the inferior most portion
of the bladder is a 8 x 14 mm area of lobulated high density along the
inferior wall of the bladder.  The rectum and sigmoid colon are within normal
limits.  There is no pelvic or inguinal adenopathy.

Bones and soft tissues: The patient is status post right hip arthroplasty. 
Lumbar spinal hardware is re- demonstrated.  The T12 compression fracture is
overall stable.  Donor sites involving the bilateral iliac wings are again
noted.  No suspicious osseous lesions are identified.




IMPRESSION:




1. No evidence pulmonary embolism.  Increased soft tissue in the left hilus is
minimally increased from the prior PET-CT in ___.  Complete collapse of
the left upper lobe is new most recent prior CT.  Small left pleural effusion.
2. Severe emphysema as before.  Increased opacity throughout the bilateral
lower lobes and right upper lobe likely reflects a combination atelectasis and
fibrosis. Mucoid impaction involving multiple segmental and subsegmental
branches.
3. Focally dilated loop of small bowel in the left upper quadrant could
reflect an early partial obstruction or ileus.  No definite transition point
is identified.
4. Appendix measures up to 6 mm however there is no periappendiceal fat
stranding or secondary signs of appendicitis in the right lower quadrant.
5. Focal area of high density along the inferior wall of the bladder most
likely related to contrast mixing in the bladder, much less likely a focal
bladder lesion.  Consider evaluation with urinalysis and nonurgent bladder
ultrasound.

FINDINGS:

CT OF THE CHEST WITHOUT AND WITH INTRAVENOUS CONTRAST:
 Unenhanced images of
the chest display no calcified atherosclerotic disease or intramural hematoma.
Contrast-enhanced images of the chest display no evidence of aortic dissection
or pulmonary embolism.  There is no pleural or pericardial effusion.  Slightly
prominent superior pericardial recess is again noted.  High right paratracheal
node is stable.  The airways are patent to the subsegmental level. Attenuation
of the lungs is somewhat mosaic related to breathing artifact and expiration
during exam acquisition, however, no focal lesions are present. The previously
identified scattered sub-5-mm pulmonary nodules appear to have resolved and
were likely artifactual or infectious/inflammatory.

Please note this examination was not tailored for infradiaphragmatic
evaluation.  Limited portions of the upper abdomen display stable appearance
of fatty attenuation of the liver but appear otherwise normal.

Bone windows:  No aggressive-appearing osseous lesions are identified.


IMPRESSION:

1.  No evidence of pulmonary embolism, pneumonia, or aortic dissection.
2.  Resolved pulmonary nodules.
3.  Fatty infiltration of the liver.

FINDINGS:



Heart and vasculature: Pulmonary vasculature is well opacified to the
subsegmental level without filling defect to indicate a pulmonary embolus.
Main pulmonary artery is enlarged to 3.5 cm which can be seen in setting of
pulmonary arterial hypertension.  The thoracic aorta is normal in caliber
without evidence of dissection or intramural hematoma.  The heart,
pericardium, and great vessels are within normal limits. No pericardial
effusion is seen.

Axilla, hila, and mediastinum: No axillary lymphadenopathy.  Conspicuous
mediastinal nodes are not enlarged by CT size criteria.  Right hilar nodes are
slightly more prominent from prior measuring up to 12 mm in short axis (2:55).
No mediastinal mass or hematoma.  An endobronchial lymph node in the lower
lobe measures 1.1 x 1.2 cm, previously 0.8 x 0.9 cm (2:60).

Pleural spaces: No pleural effusion or pneumothorax.

Lungs/airways: There are bilateral lower lobe hypoventilatory changes
including atelectasis with bronchovascular crowding and mild bronchial wall
thickening diffusely.  Airways are patent to the segmental level.  There are
multiple pulmonary nodules measuring 7 mm in left lower lobe (2:67) and 5 mm
in the right middle lobe (2:62), similar from prior.  There is mild
centrilobular emphysema.

Base of neck: Visualized portions of the base of the neck show no abnormality.

Abdomen: The portions of the upper abdomen are unremarkable.

Bones: No suspicious osseous abnormality is seen.? There is no acute fracture.
There is a kyphotic curvature of the thoracic spine.


IMPRESSION:



1. No evidence of pulmonary embolism or aortic abnormality.
2. Hypoventilatory changes and small airway disease seen on a background of
emphysema.
3. Nonspecific right hilar nodes are slightly more prominent from prior
measuring up to 12 mm, previously 10 mm.
4. Main pulmonary artery is enlarged to 3.5 cm which can be seen in the
setting of pulmonary arterial hypertension.
5. Multiple pulmonary nodules measuring up to 7 mm in the left lower lobe are
stable from prior.

FINDINGS:



Chest:
Heart and vasculature: Pulmonary vasculature is well opacified without filling
defect to indicate a definite pulmonary embolus.  The thoracic aorta is normal
in caliber without evidence of dissection or intramural hematoma.  The heart,
pericardium, and great vessels are within normal limits. No pericardial

Axilla, hila, and mediastinum: No axillary, mediastinal, or hilar
lymphadenopathy is present.  No mediastinal mass.

Pleural spaces: No pleural effusion or pneumothorax.

Lungs/airways: Mild ground-glass opacities are seen predominantly in the lower

Base of neck: Visualized portions of the base of the neck show no abnormality.
There is mild increased sclerosis along the inferior endplate of the T8
vertebrae, possibly degenerative.


IMPRESSION:



1. No evidence of pulmonary embolus or aortic abnormality.
2. Mild ground-glass opacities are predominantly seen in the lower lobes,
which is nonspecific but may be due to aspiration versus mild edema.

FINDINGS:

 No filling defects are present within the pulmonary arteries to
suggest pulmonary embolism.  Severe atherosclerotic calcifications of the
aortic arch and descending thoracic aorta appears stable since recent
comparison with irregular mural thrombus and areas of ulceration.  No thoracic
aortic dissection is present.  Changes consistent with chronic pulmonary
infection with bronchiectasis and mucoid impaction are unchanged over the
short interval.  Evidence of prior granulomatous insult also unchanged.

Lower thoracic vertebral wedge compression deformity and calcification of the
anterior longitudinal ligament, unchanged.


IMPRESSION:

1.  No evidence of acute pulmonary embolism or thoracic aortic dissection.
2.  The findings consistent with bronchiectasis, chronic pulmonary infection
and healed granulomatous insult are unchanged over the short interval.
3.  Severe calcified atherosclerotic disease with ulcerated plaques throughout
the thoracic aorta is unchanged over the short interval.

FINDINGS:



The included portion of the lower thyroid is normal.

There is no supraclavicular or axillary lymphadenopathy. Extensive mediastinal
and hilar lymphadenopathy is not changed since the prior study. The great
vessels are normal caliber.  There is no evidence of pulmonary embolism down
to the segmental level. The heart size is normal.  No pericardial effusion.

The airways are patent to subsegmental levels.

A left lower lobe consolidation with atelectasis and collapse is again seen. 
Since the prior examination there has been interval increase in size of
innumerable bilateral nodules as well as more extensive consolidation in the
lingula.  A dominant mass in the right lung base has increased in size from
the prior exam now measuring 4.5 x 3.8 cm (previously 4.1 x 2.8 cm). 
Postsurgical changes are again noted from prior left lower lobe wedge
resections and a prior right upper lobectomy. Centrilobular emphysematous
changes, similar in appearance to the prior exam. There is no evidence of
pneumothorax. Persistent pleural thickening at the left base is not
significantly changed.

Extensive calcifications seen throughout the pancreas are unchanged from the
prior exam likely related to prior pancreatitis. There is no evidence of
peripancreatic inflammation or fat stranding.  The remainder of the visualized
portion of the upper abdomen is normal appearing.

Osseous structures: No focal lytic or sclerotic lesion concerning for
malignancy.  Paraspinal soft tissue densities the largest measuring 0.6 x 1.3
cm (series 3, image 172, 189) likely represent metastatic disease.  Coles
right twelfth rib fractures identified.


IMPRESSION:



No evidence of pulmonary embolism.

Chronic left lower lobe consolidation is moderately increased in size from the
prior examination is likely related to underlying malignancy and adjacent
atelectasis, superimposed infection is not excluded.

4.5 x 3.8 cm mass at the base of the right lung is increased in size from the
prior exam when it measured 4.1 by 2.8 cm. Multiple pulmonary nodules are
again demonstrated and are increased in size from the prior.  Paraspinal soft
tissue densities on the left as described above likely represent metastatic
foci.

Chronic pancreatitis with no evidence of acute inflammation.

FINDINGS:



The aorta and its major branch vessels are patent, with no evidence of
stenosis, occlusion, dissection, or aneurysmal formation.  There is no
evidence of penetrating atherosclerotic ulcer or aortic arch atheroma present.

The pulmonary arteries are well opacified to the subsegmental level, with no
evidence of filling defect within the main, right, left, lobar, segmental or
subsegmental pulmonary arteries.  The main and right pulmonary arteries are
normal in caliber, and there is no evidence of right heart strain.

There is no supraclavicular, axillary, mediastinal, or hilar lymphadenopathy. 
The thyroid gland appears unremarkable.

There is no evidence of pericardial effusion.  The heart is normal in size. 
There is no pleural effusion.

Mild bibasilar atelectasis.  The lungs are otherwise clear.  The airways are
patent to the subsegmental level.

Limited images of the upper abdomen are notable for a 1.4 x 1 cm accessory
spleen.  No significant change in the numerous hepatic cysts, largest
measuring 5.7 x 6.2 cm (2:80) within segment 6.

No lytic or blastic osseous lesion suspicious for malignancy is identified.


IMPRESSION:



No evidence of pulmonary embolism or aortic abnormality.

FINDINGS:



Chest:

Heart and vasculature: Pulmonary vasculature is well opacified to the
subsegmental level without filling defect to indicate a pulmonary embolus. 
The thoracic aorta is normal in caliber without evidence of dissection or

Axilla, hila, and mediastinum: No axillary, mediastinal, or hilar

Pleural spaces: No pleural effusion or pneumothorax.

Lungs/airways:  The airways are patent to the level of the segmental bronchi

Base of neck: Visualized portions of the base of the neck show no abnormality.

Abdomen:

Hepatobiliary: The liver demonstrates homogenous attenuation throughout.

Pancreas: The pancreas has normal attenuation throughout, without evidence of

Spleen: The spleen shows normal size and attenuation throughout, without

Adrenals:  Right adrenal gland is surgically absent.  Stable nodularity of the

Urinary: Status post right nephrectomy.  No significant interval change in

Gastrointestinal: Small hiatal hernia.  Small bowel loops demonstrate normal

Pelvis:

The urinary bladder and distal ureters are unremarkable.  There is no free

Reproductive organs: The prostate and seminal vesicles are unremarkable.

Lymph nodes: There is no retroperitoneal or mesenteric lymphadenopathy.  There

Vascular: There is no abdominal aortic aneurysm.  Very minimal atherosclerotic

Bones and soft tissues: There is no evidence of worrisome osseous lesions or

1. No evidence of pulmonary embolism.
2. Stable 3 mm right middle lobe nodule.
3. No acute intra-abdominal process.
4. Stable size of a 1.6 x 1.5 cm soft tissue nodule along the superior aspect
of the right nephrectomy bed.

FINDINGS:



No axillary, mediastinal, or hilar lymphadenopathy by CT size criteria.

Heart size is normal, and there is no pericardial effusion.  Mild coronary

Airways are patent to the segmental bronchi bilaterally.  Mild upper lobe

No concerning lytic or sclerotic lesions.  No acute fracture.  Chest wall is

Included images of the upper abdomen are grossly unremarkable.


IMPRESSION:



1. No evidence of pulmonary embolism or aortic abnormality.
2. Mild upper lobe predominant centrilobular emphysema.
3. Coronary artery calcifications.
4. Possible pulmonary arterial hypertension.
5. Probable partial anomalous pulmonary venous return.

FINDINGS:



Heart and vasculature: Pulmonary vasculature is well opacified to the

Pleural spaces: Redemonstration of right apical pleural thickening, similar in

Base of neck: There is redemonstration of a 0.8 x 0.8 cm hypodense left

Abdomen:  Included portion of the upper abdomen is notable for partial

Bones: Adjacent to the right apical lung mass, there is irregularity of the

IMPRESSION:



1. No evidence of pulmonary embolism or aortic abnormality.
2. Redemonstration of a 4.1 cm right apical lung mass, unchanged in size and
appearance compared to most recent prior CT dated ___.  Similar to
prior exam, there is cortical irregularity in the posterolateral right third
rib, suggestive of malignant involvement.
3. Multiple bilateral solid pulmonary nodules are similar in size and
appearance compared to CT dated ___.
4. Multiple hypodense hepatic metastatic lesions are again partially
visualized, corresponding to known metastatic disease.

FINDINGS:
